title: Quiz 3: Communication & Assertiveness
topicName: Essential Knowledge and Skills for Healthcare Assistants
description: Evaluate your communication skills, understanding of non-verbal cues, and ability to be assertive.

questions.question: According to research (Borg 2010), approximately what percentage of 'emotional meaning' is conveyed through facial expressions and tone of voice (non-verbal)?
questions.explanation: 93% is non-verbal (facial expressions/tone), while only 7% is the actual words spoken.
questions.hint: It is the vast majority of communication.

questions.question: Which of the following are barriers to effective communication? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Jargon, different agendas, fear, and distractions block communication. Active listening is a facilitator, not a barrier.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for the 'Broken Record Technique' in a logical flow:

items.text: State your refusal calmly ('I cannot do that')
Listen to the other person's persistence
Repeat the same refusal using similar words without getting angry
Offer a compromise if appropriate (e.g., speak to manager)

questions.explanation: The technique involves stating your position, maintaining it calmly despite pressure (repeating), and offering a constructive path forward if needed.

questions.question: The basic difference between being ___BLANK___ and being aggressive is how our words and behaviour affect the rights and well-being of others.
questions.explanation: Assertiveness respects others' rights; aggression ignores them.
questions.hint: The positive skill we are trying to learn.

questions.question: When communicating with a patient with dementia, you should speak quickly and correct every mistake they make to keep them grounded in reality.
questions.explanation: You should speak slowly, be patient, and avoid correcting mistakes or confrontation, as this causes stress. Validate their feelings instead.
questions.hint: Is confrontation helpful for someone with dementia?

questions.question: Match the body language/behavior to the communication style:

pairs.right: Dominating, verbal abuse, ignores others' rights

questions.explanation: Definitions of the three main behavior types plus an example of non-verbal posture.
questions.hint: Passive is 'doormat', Aggressive is 'bully', Assertive is 'adult'.

questions.question: What is the term for listening that involves hearing what is being said (and not said), maintaining eye contact, and reflecting back understanding?
questions.explanation: Active listening is a structured way of listening and responding to others.

questions.question: Why is 'overfamiliarity' considered a barrier to communication?

options.text: It makes patients feel too relaxed
It may be interpreted as disrespectful or patronizing (e.g., calling someone 'darling')

questions.explanation: Terms like 'love' or 'darling' can be seen as disrespectful, especially by older patients who prefer formal titles.
questions.hint: Think about how an older patient might feel being called 'darling' by a stranger.

questions.question: If you receive unfair or invalid criticism, you should take it personally and allow it to lower your self-esteem.
questions.explanation: Assertiveness involves determining if criticism is valid. If invalid, you should not take it on board or let it affect your self-esteem.
questions.hint: Should you accept criticism that isn't true?

questions.question: Which of these is a benefit of effective communication mentioned in the text?
questions.explanation: Good communication leads to better compliance, reduced pain/anxiety, and fewer complaints.
questions.hint: Does it make the patient follow instructions better?
